title: mirror readers share brexit views
story: NewsMirror readers share Brexit views on third anniversary of EU referendumIn Huddersfield and Hull, in Devon and Bristol, Edinburgh and Brecon, pairs of people matched by our ground-breaking Britain Talks project met across the political ide.ShareCommentsByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnist:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsHendrik de Jong and Humaira Ali discuss their conflicting views "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritain stopped shouting and started listening yesterday and no milkshakes were thrown. Pairs of people matched by our ground-breaking Britain Talks project met across the political ide and learned to listen. Fittingly they chatted as communities nationwide reached out to each other for the third year of the Great Get Together in memory of murdered MP Jo Cox. The Mirror partnered with theand regional newspapers across Reach PLC to find the widest possible audience. More than , readers were brave enough to sign up, and hundreds finally met their political opposite yesterday in Huddersfield and Hull, Devon and Bristol, Edinburgh and Brecon. Three years after the EU referendum result, the aim was to escape our own social bubbles, and to share a cup of tea or have a pint in the sunshine with someone of opposing opinions.    Our matches joined tens of thousands who attended events remembering Jo, who was killed a right-wing extemist, and honouring her belief that we have “more in common than that which ides us”. Arch Brexiteer Claire Milne, , had a robust exchanges in Edinburgh with ardent Remainer company director John Birchmore. It left them keen to chat again. Afterwards Claire laughed: “No milkshakes were thrown.” Our couples aired their strong views about Brexit , immigration, climate change, Donald Trump, austerity and crime. They came together over the NHS, their local football team, public transport and most of all the need to talk to each other. Described as “political Tinder”, Britain Talks is based on My Country Talks – an initiative from German news website Zeit Online. The original experiment has been repeated in Italy, Norway, Denmark, Switzerland and Austria, as Europe confronts its isions.  When we began the project  weeks ago, our poll showed Brexit was the issue people felt ided them most – at %. Immigration followed at %, left-right politics at % and wealth at %. The same poll showed % felt our country was ided – with % arguing with family or friends about Brexit several times a week. One in four felt angry with people who voted the opposite way to them on Brexit day, and % said people had become less tolerant since. But our polling also showed % wishing the UK was more united. And % liked the idea of chatting to someone with an opposing view without anyone losing their temper. In a Britain re-polarised since Brexit by a lack of progress in Parliament, the EU elections and now the Tory leadership race, finding , people prepared to meet is a symbol of hope. Here are snapshots of some of the Britain Talks discussions...Read more about Britain Talks at mirror britaintalksLondon     Amid the sociable swirl at a London community festival, two very dferent people smile out of one large chequered photo frame. The words “we’ve got more in common” wrapped in large letters around the faces of Hendrik de Jong, , and Humaira Ali, . Ex-police officer Hendrik supports the Brexit Party and wants Britain to leave the EU immediately. Humaira is a Lib Dem councillor for Southwark. They met at the Great British Get Together happening on London’s Bankside – a festival inspired by the work of murdered MP Jo Cox. Humaira says: “I think there’s a lot we agree onyou take out Brexit – health, housing, social responsibility and the environment. Hendrik adds: “We both believe in equality.” The pair even agreed to meet up again. Hendrik says: “After Holland joined the EU my family lost money on their pensions. We were % worse off afterwards and had no vote on it. British politicians now need to get a better deal for Britain.” But Humaira says: “We already have the best deal. Margaret Thatcher negotiated it years ago. We’re not in Schengen and we don’t have the euro.” Huddersfield  When Phil Wood meets Adam Rana in a cafe, the Remainer is worried that Adam’s entrepreneurial side will make his views hard to swallow. But after meeting, community development consultant Phil, , realises that despite their political dferences his concerns are misplaced. Self-confessed “hopeless idealist” Phil says: “I think we want the same thing really – a better world where people take more care of each other, take more responsibility and are prepared to go out of their way rather than just think about themselves.” Adam, , who trades over the internet, says: “I’m a firm believer in leaving the EU because it will help Britain’s trading position.” Adam, a full-time carer for his we, believes a thriving economy will create better public services.But Phil warns it could lead to “dog eat dog”. Adam says of the meeting: “It has opened my views up to someone ’s way of thinking. I feel the focus is on ‘me, me ,me’.” And he laments the way the Government shuns the elderly, forcing them to rely on charity. “It seems a case of ‘Thanks for the service, we don’t want to know about you’.” Manchester  One is a die-hard Brexiteer, the other a dedicated Remainer. “I’m sick of being called a Remoaner when all I want is a better future for my kids,” says catering assistant Donna Chadwick, , a mum of two teenage boys from Heywood. Terence Farrand, , a semi-retired builder, has lived in Europe but is clear we should be out of the EU, with no second vote. “If we do that, democracy is finished,” he warns. For Terence, married with four grandchildren and three great-grandchildren, immigration means pressure on the NHS. “You can’t get an appointment when you need one,” he says. Donna says: “Yes, services are struggling but that’s more about investment.” But when Donna and Terence, from Whitefield, meet over wine and coffee, they find a shared love of Bury Football Club – and agree the NHS needs cash. “It’s been good to have someone to listen to what I’ve got to say, without being shouted down,” says Donna, as they decide to meet up again this week. Terence agrees. “I have strong opinions but we live in a world where people are scared to express them, or to speak to someone with dferent views.” Brecon Beacons  In the foothills of the Brecon Beacons, Annette Lloyd and Emily Durrant are searching for common ground in a canal-side cafe. Emily was not even born when Annette started her first job in a factory, and they are never going to agree on Brexit. But there is much to unite them... Emily, , juggles two young children and three jobs, including her role as a Green Party county councillor. Meanwhile, Annette, , toils on nights as a support worker and helps to look after her grandchildren and elderly relatives. Both agree low wages and austerity mean families are under pressure. Emily, who also works for the National Trust, says: “The economy doesn’t work for families. Wages are just too low.” Emily, from Llangorse, Powys, is a committed Remainer. Annette, , favours Brexit. “It’ll get the factories working again,” she says. But Emily finds common ground with Annette, from Llandeilo Graban, over the NHS. “We’ve been sold down the river,” they agree. Before going their separate ways, Annette and Emily hug and laugh. “When you look at the bigger picture,” Annette says, “we’re very similar.” Stoke  In the leafy hamlet of Stockton Brook, near Stoke- on-Trent, it’s clear William Alcock and Louise Adams both feel passionately about their city. William, , served in the Army for  years before joining the police and Louise, , is a freelance artist who works in the ceramics industry. And William, now retired, doesn’t hesitate to air his views about Brexit. He says: “We are spending £million a day to be in the EU. That is what we are paying the thieves in Brussels. They have taken away our sovereignty. “We are losing control of this country and we are losing control of our cultures.” Louise believes we should stay in the EU. “It will allow us to build on love, peace and friendships,” she says. “Being part of the EU has allowed us to work together, share cultures and ideas.” Louise believes that with the right investment refugees can settle here successfully but William is concerned about the pressure it puts on the NHS. But they agree they both want what’s best for their beloved country.

title: newsnights emily maitlis slammed letting
story: NewsNewsnights Emily Maitlis slammed for letting dog sleep on seat of packed trainEXCLUSIVE - The presenter and journalist, , was seen travelling with her whippet, Moody, on a busy Great Western train to London Paddington this afternoonShareCommentsByAmy Coles:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsBBC Newsnight Presenter Emily Maitlis let her dog curl up on a train seat "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNewsnight host Emily Maitlis has been hounded for letting her dog sleep on a seat on packed train. The presenter and journalist, , was seen travelling with her whippet, Moody, on a busy Great Western train to London Paddington this afternoon. There were few empty seats but she let her dog curl up next to her. Other paying passengers had to look ­where for a place to sit. A witness said: “I was really surprised to see the dog on the seat. There wasn’t even a mat or newspaper underneath it. “For someone who is very much in the public eye, who holds politicians to account, I would have expected her to behave better. “When I boarded the train it was really busy. A lady was looking for a seat and ended up sitting behind Emily and not on a seat with a table, where there is more room.  “Some people chose to stand, as there were few spare seats. It shows a lack of respect for other passengers to feel it appropriate for dogs to sit on seats meant for passengers. “It’s a question of courtesy and consideration for others. The dog should have been on the floor. It could have been dirty or could have had ticks or fleas.” The witness, going from Reading, Berks to London, said Maitlis’s dog slept on the Penzance to London service for at least  minutes before Paddington. Last week, Maitlis, one of ­Britain’s most respected interviewers, was criticised over her handling of the televised Tory leadership debate with hundreds of BBC viewers accusing her of losing control of the candidates and failing to get answers. Bruce Williamson, of the ­Railfuture campaign, said expensive train fares mean “people who have paid for a ticket must come first”.  He added: “I’m surprised a conductor didn’t say something about it. I’m a dog lover, but dogs on trains are essentially luggage and second-class ­citizens to humans. Seats should be reserved for first and ­foremost for humans. “It just highlights the level of overcrowding on our railways and the shortage of seats.” A railway passenger group said Maitlis broke one of the network operators rules. Fraser Pithie, of the Campaign for Rail, said: “The rules do not give animals any right to take up seats. Dogs must remain on the floor. Even guide dogs are not allowed on seats. A train guard should have spoken to her.”  A spokesman from Great Western confirmed the company does allow people to bring animals on their trains but said they are never allowed on seats. National Rail conditions say: “Animals are not allowed on seats in any circumstances” and warn a charge could be madeanimals occupy seats. In a statement, Maitlis said: “There was no one without a seat looking to sit down. “The dog was under the table for the first three hours of the journey whilst four people sat down at it. He came on to the seat for the last  minutes of the journey when the seat next to me became free.”

title: three years after eu referendum
story: NewsThree years after the EU referendum Britain is more ided than ever on BrexitAs Westminster fails to find solutions, more people favour “no deal” or a second referendumShareByRyan Fletcher:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsStuart Lilland Nick Thompson both from Hull, discuss Brexit "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Three years after the EU referendum, Britain is more ided than ever on Brexit .As Westminster fails to find solutions, more people favour “no deal” or a second referendum. But left-right politics, Scottish independence, trans rights and veganism are also among the topics which we are ided over. Hull voted by .% to .% to leave the EU. Locals Nick Thompson and Stuart Lill dfer over Brexit, but agree politicians are failing to bridge the ide. Marketing worker Nick, , is a Remainer, while Stuart, , a carer for his autistic son, is a Leaver. Stuart says: “It’s very much a case of, ‘You must be a racistyou voted Brexit’. Tell that to my Polish better half and Polish kids. “I’m still a Brexiteer, I just care about my country.” Nick says: “It’s wrong that people on the Leave side are labelled like that. Part of the trouble is representation. You don’t feel represented and I don’t feel represented either.  “It’s just I don’t think that situation will change by leaving the EU.” Stuart and Nick both feel public services are being starved of resources but dfer on the causes. Nick says: “Austerity was a choice by the UK Government and nothing to do with Europe. “Some say it had to be made, but it didn’t. When you think they can’t cut any more, they cut more and more.“As one of the richest countries in the world, we shouldn’t have foodbanksall over the place.We shouldn’t have all these people sleeping on the streets.” Stuart thinks immigration has added to the pressures on public services. He says: “You can’t argue that the numbers that have come haven’t added to the burden on things such as housing and hospital waiting lists. “Populism is rising across Europe because of the hatred of the EU.” Nick worries the power will go from the EU to the UK Government which is “a lot less trustworthy than Brussels”. Stuart agrees: “I don’t think there’s a political party out there that is really doing a very good job.” Nick says: “We both feel politically homeless. Politics now is a shambles.” Devon  * A clash over climate change got a cool reaction from Green Party voter Adrian Allery when UKIP supporter Andre Savini said blaming CO for global warming was hot air. Proving it is possible to disagree very agreeably, -year-old antiques shop manager Andre and deep-sea ship pilot Adrian, , shared their views over a pint in Honiton, Devon. Leave voter Andre argued: “It’s a myth that CO is the main driver in climate change.” Remain voter Adrian thought the two-hour pub chat raised interesting points. “But I simply do not agree with Andre that climate change is a scam to raise taxes, that big pharma is toxic or that the EU is an evil Stalinist empire,” he said. But even these unlikely lads found common ground. They agreed faith schools should be abolished and the first-past-the-post political system is not fit for purpose. Despite his Italian roots, Andre believes immigration has to be controlled, saying he supports UKIP because “mainstream parties are just there for big business”. While Adrian said, “I felt Andre cherry picks facts that back his theories. I was glad we met, I’d do it again.” Bristol  When two Bristol locals went on a debating date in the park, they found plenty of common ground. The sun smiled on -year-old electrician James Pierce and NHS administrator Jane Westmead, , and they found their dferences melting away.Poetry lover Jane said: “It went really, really well. James was very honest, and we were still chatting away hours later when we bumped into Bristol’s Labour mayor Marvin Rees in the park and he joined in the discussions.”Leave voter James said he was expecting Jane to be shouty and unwilling to listen, but instead she was fun and open-minded. He explained: “Although we disagree on many issues, we have the same goals. Jane voted for Remain, but she respects the result and neither of us want a second referendum.” Left-voting Jane admits she had preconceived notions about staunch Tory James. But she said: “We both love the NHS but think it’s very inefficient. London  Retired local government officer Ken Hickford and charity worker Billy Beckett met in a North London Italian restaurant for their debate. Ken, , wants Britain out of Europe but Billy, , thinks unity makes us stronger and more secure. Ken reckons refugees should get sanctuary but be sent home when their nation is back on its feet as the UK’s infrastructure is close to collapse. Billy thinks, by then, they may bring all sorts of value to us and austerity may be more to blame for the problems. They are polar opposites but Ken said: “I liked Billy’s enthusiasm. He seems to believe in politicians and our conversation did give me a boost.” Billy liked talking to someone with dferent views. He said: “Social media confirms our own biases. This has been a way to step out of it.” Liverpool  Remainer Michelle Bennett and committed Brexiteer Dave Jones live just a few miles away from each other. But, on paper, they are poles apart. It isn’t long before Michelle, , a trained social worker, and retired community nurse Dave, , are setting the world to rights over a coffee. Mum-of-one Michelle voted to Leave but has since become a Remainer – worried about the prospect of no deal – and wants a second referendum. “So much has changed since then,” she says. Dave, a mild-mannered father of four from Wavertree, disagrees. He said: “We need to respect the result.” But, both are clear the NHS needs to be valued and we should help refugees. Michelle lives in Toxteth – where Dave was born – and they leave, laughing, and admitting they’d loved the experience. Dave even offered Michelle a lt home. Edinburgh  They met as strangers on a bridge coming from opposite sides. John Birchmore, , is a company director and such an ardent Remainer he moved his company’s centre of operations to Latvia and has a new Irish passport. John’s campaigning for a People’s Vote and even has politics discussions with his postie, who decried the EU as non-democratic while delivering his postal vote. “He failed to see the irony,” says John. Claire Milne, , is a Jacob Rees-Mogg-loving, Tory-voting Brexiteer. At home, she has been told she’s only allowed to speak three sentences of politics a day because, “I tend to go on a bit”. As they settle down to a cool drink in the shade of Edinburgh’s Princes Street Gardens, their conversation heats up until there is table thumping and exclamations of “cobblers!” and “b*****ks!”. John says: “There were lots of myths pedalled by Brexiteers about not being able to sell crooked cucumbers.” Claire retorts: “Bananas!” It’s a robust  minutes. At times, their voices rise higher than a nearby pipes and drums contest. But, at the end, both are keen to chat again. “It’s great to listen to someone who is well informed and can be challenged on details,” John says. Claire laughs: “And no milkshakes were thrown.”

title: i went undercover told take
story: NewsI went undercover - and was told to take explosives hidden in teddy bears to schoolDavid Rupert was drawn into the dark and dangerous world of terrorism to become a double agent working for the FBI inside the IRA - this is his incredible story in his own wordsShareComments"ByDavid Rupert :,  JUN NewsDavid Rupert who infiltrated the Real IRA in Ireland while working for the FBI "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt was , and I’d been living in West Florida while running my trucking company. I was in Tampa with friends when I heard folk music coming from an Irish and Scottish bar, The Harp  Thistle. I liked the music, so I went in. There one night, I met this beautul, lively woman named Linda. We started dating and I soon learned she was heavily involved with Noraid, the US political wing of the Provisional IRA. I didn’t know much about the Northern Ireland conflict, but feigned interest because I liked Linda. She invited me to Ireland and I accepted. We drove up to Sligo and Donegal on the west coast – Linda knew the owners of pro-IRA bars and they all knew her by her first name.    One of the owners, Joe O’Neill, was a long-time IRA man and he took a liking to me and taught me about Irish history. Linda and I broke up soon afterwards, but I was hooked on Ireland by then and went back by myself to meet Joe and other IRA men.I didn’t know it at the time, but the Irish police were photographing me with IRA members and sent the photos to the FBI.One day an FBI agent showed up at my trucking company office. I said I didn’t know about anything illegal, which was the truth, but he insisted on coming back to ask questions. He then said the FBI would pay for me and my new girlfriend, Maureen, to fly to Ireland when we wanted, in exchange for small pieces of information about the IRA.    As I didn’t know anything, I felt I might as well let the FBI pay for our holidays. So we would go back and forth to Ireland and give the FBI very little. Then one day, Joe invited me to the room he used for IRA meetings, which was above his pub. He said he wanted me to smuggle explosive parts from the US, and gave me the address of a primary school where I should send them – the plastic explosives were to be hidden in teddy bears, detonating cord disguised as skipping rope, and electronic parts hidden in radios. This made me flinch – the idea of sending explosives to a school. I said I would, but I passed on the info to the FBI, and soon the spying operation became more serious. I wanted to move to Ireland anyway, and the FBI agreed to pay for the lease on a pub on the Irish border, near Joe’s bar. My bar quickly became a gathering point for IRA members and the information started to come in.  I liked the customers, but some moments shocked me – like watching a granny bouncing a young boy on her knee and telling him some day he would shoot policemen in the North. Pretty soon the FBI asked me to meet MI, which was keen to have spies in the IRA groups that were opposed to the Northern Ireland peace process. I flew to London for a debrief with an MI agent, and soon I was reporting to them as well. Then, in August , the Real IRA set off a car bomb in Omagh, which killed  civilians, including a mother nine months pregnant with twins. Later, Maureen and I watched a documentary about children injured in the Omagh bomb, one of whom was blinded. It was devastating.  I had to remind myself these were the people I was dealing with. There was a tendency to see them as friends, but I also had to find those other feelings at the back of that – revulsion and disgust for what was happening to innocent people. Then I was introduced to the Real IRA’s leader, Mickey McKevitt, along with several of his top men. He liked me straight away, and I liked him. He was easy to talk to and was enthusiastic about American fund-raising money and my ability to get weapons and bomb parts in the US.Over time, I learned he had a sleeper agentin the US who would be brought to the UK when the time was right to shoot Tony Blair , or some other high-level British establishment figure.I met the sleeper several times in Massachusetts and he was keen toget weapons moving to Ireland.Eventually, Mickey suggested I sit on the Real IRA’s army council. I wouldn’t have voting rights, but I could very to US supporters that their money was being well spent and be able to report back on weapons and bomb parts needed by the Real IRA.The army council meetings were held at a farmer’s cottage in the mountains on the border, where the farmer’s we would make us tea, while he discussed bombings in England and assassinations of police officers.I would send detailed emails to the FBI and MI of what was happening.My scariest moment came when I attended the ‘engineering’ orbomb-making meetings.I brought along encryption software for the team that had been doctored by MI.  One of the top bomb makers was very suspicious and said that it might have been tampered with. My heart was racing and I was sweating. I was petried and couldn’t sleep that night. I was really on edge, wonderingthe Real IRA would find out that the encryption software had been compromised. What would happen to me and Maureenthey did  I knew about the torture and death that came to other IRA informers. There was a case in which a woman was beaten to death by three IRA members, while with another informer, they set up a roadblock, shot him in the back of the head and rolled his car into the canal. The police didn’t find his body for two years. That would have been my fate.  I began to wonder how much longer we could stay in this le. Mickey told me he was looking for a foreign sponsor to supply them with weapons and was interested in Saddam Hussein.I told MI, who were excited and saw it as an opportunity to ensnare the Real IRA.It was agreed with MI that I would testy against some of the Real IRA leadership, and in one day there were arrests of leaders in the south of Ireland, the north, and the US. I was flown to a US airbase in Britain, as I was due to testy against three Real IRA council members who had set up meetings with Saddam Hussein’s agents . Then I flew on the British royal jet to testy against Mickey McKevitt, who was arrested at his home. He wasn’t one bit happy to see me this time, and glared at me. I was nervous at the beginning of the trial – there were lots of TV cameras outside the court, and army snipers on the roof of the courtroom. Mickey’s barrister cross-examined me for two weeks. It was gruelling.  After I finally finished testying, the SAS took me by Hercules plane out of Ireland forever. The most stressful part was after I had finished testying and ed to the US in hiding. I had all this adrenaline running through me for years. Suddenly I wasn’t living on the edge any more and couldn’t handle my emotions. I went on anti-depressants and anti-anxiety drugs, Maureen went on them too. We couldn’t adjust to this new passive world after so many years undercover, but I eventually learned to get on with le and enjoy myself. Mickey McKevitt was jailed for  years and I know he will never forgive me. Still, after the Omagh bomb, I have no regrets about what I did.  I also earned millions of dollars from the FBI, but I can never work again because the Real IRA would catch up with me. I loved being a spy, but I will be looking over my shoulder for the rest of my le.- Get % off  The Accidental Spy  with offer code R Plus PP. Call    or order online at Mirror Books

title: 3 years black student university
story: NewsMy  years as a black student at university - and why I would never do it againKent Caribbean Union co-founder Jessica Mayne reveals how tough le was for her on the Canterbury campusShareCommentsByJessica Mayne:,  JUN NewsThe student revealed her tough experiences "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA recent graduate from the University of Kent has told of her dficult experiences as a black student.Jessica Mayne completed a religious studies degree at the universityaposs Canterbury campus but has now opened up about the challenges of leaving home, enduring racial slurs and an awful experience in her first month of studying, Kent Live reports.Year  They say the first year of university is the best. I couldnapost relate. The University of Kent in Canterbury was my number one choice. While attending an applicant day, I was immediately put at ease. The campus was beautul, my desired course— religious studies — was being taught by world class scholars, and it was not too far from my home in Bromley. I instantly knew it was  meant to be.    It is, however, an understatement to say that in September   I was nervous. I dreamt and imagined what this new phase of my le would entail but had no idea what to expect.The numerous Netflix films I watched, exhibiting the American college experience would never prepare me for the journey I was about to embark on.“We hate you you f******  n*****” was the racial abuse directed at me by my housemate in my halls of residence.  My housemates took personal offence to the fact that I did not want to drink and go out with them. I was friendly but reserved because I was still acclimatising to le away from home. Additionally, getting drunk every night and being asked to clean up vomit was not my idea of fun.  It was only the first couple of months of university, I wanted to take my time. I had worked so hard to get into university. It goes without saying that I quickly became the least favourite person in the house. Living in the most aesthetically pleasing accommodation, Turing College,  on campus — jokingly referred to by some as Beverly Hills — could not compensate for living with people I did not get on with. My bedroom not only became the place where I had to store my kitchenware, it became my sanctuary. However, even my room couldnapost shield me from the unedying sight of  strangers using my shared toilet with the door wide open! It is a notorious attitude that because the first year does not contribute to your final degree, you do not have to work as hard. Whilst many of  my first year counterparts were partying nightly, I was determined to excel academically from the outset.      Consequently, I was a first year student stressing out like a final year one. Year  Carrying the weight of isolation that the  first year brought, I feared that my bedroom, my place of refuge, had become a cage, locking me away from all of the enjoyable experiences that the University of Kent had to offer. I did not regret working hard in my first year because that is what I set out to do.  I did, however, feel that consuming myself solely with my degree was unhealthy and not conducive to forming meaningful relationships and enjoying my university experience outside of academia.    As a British-Jamaican person, I noticed that a wider isolation  existed among students of caribbean heritage at university. In response to this,  I co-founded a society, with Louise Mayne, where  such students could be represented and elevated. This society, Kent Caribbean Union , aims to rewrite the narrative by educating, raising aspirations and inspiring all students to fulfill their potential. It was, therefore, to my dismay that KCU had to fight for the right to exist. Even the backdrop of the th anniversary year of Windrush and the infamous Windrush scandal would not motivate some members of the student body  to acknowledge our right to be represented. Second year was the year where I really had to strengthen my time management skills. In addition to my responsibilities to the society, I  devoted time to being an academic mentor and outreach ambassador. By this stage I no longer lived on campus, but privately rented of off campus   with my sister and two other friends  — whom I had met during the previous year. The courses we studied were religious studies, maths and law. The novelty of not living under your parent’s roof soon wears off as you become burdened with the responsibilities that come with independent living. Luckily, I moved to Canterbury from Bromley and so was never too far away toto home comforts. Year  With Canterbury Cathedral within a stoneaposs throw of my house, I was ashamed that by my final year I still I had not managed to visit it. I began to explore the beauty of the city. Walking down the quaint cobbled streets served as a constant reminder of the rich heritage of this city. The contrast between the lively and progressive student city with the historic sights and buildings never ceases to fascinate me. This amazement, however, quickly dwindled when I noticed the visible homelessness, something I did not see as often in Bromley. Canterbury is home to three dferent universities, accommodating thousands of UK and international students. It is evident that much of the  ersity present in the city can largely be attributed to the substantial student population.    I always wonder what Canterbury would look like without such student residents  This year was the most rewarding as the society soared to new heights. At the Kent Student Awards , KCU, was awarded ‘Group of the Year’ and ‘Outstanding International Multicultural Initiative of the Year.’ We were also shortlisted for Outstanding Contribution to Equality, Diversity and Inclusivity, being the only group to be shortlisted in more than one category. The awards ceremony celebrated other inspiring students who are contributing to changes in government policy, campaigning against social injustices and raising awareness of illnesses. Considering this, not only is there evidently hope for my generation, but I am proud to have unapologetically fought for something I believe in. Whilst my three years in Canterbury have been physically, mentally and emotionally draining, they have built my character,confidence and inner strength. So would I do it again  No. Am I happy that I did it  % yes. I have left Canterbury, not just with a st class degree, but with a better sense of self. University of Kent statement A spokesman for the university said: We do not tolerate any form of racism or racist abuse. We are committed to the promotion of ersity and inclusivity within the University community, and this commitment is underpinned in our Institutional Strategic Plan. Through the Student Charter that we developed with Kent Union, the University has also committed to the fair and equal treatment of every person, and to ersity and inclusivity in its student and staff community.    Our students are also committed to treating fellow students, University staff, visitors, neighbours and all people equally and respectfully, regardless of gender, religion, community background, nationality, race ethnic origin, disability, marital or other status, responsibilities, sexual orientation or age.   In order to ensure all students are fully informed when it comes to treating everyone with dignity and respect we created the aposExpect Respect @ Kent’ e-learning module which all students must complete within six months of arriving at Kent.

title: around 16 atms day converted
story: NewsAround  ATMs a day converted from free to charging harming vulnerable the mostEXCLUSIVE - Figures show nearly , fee-charging ATMs appeared in the first four months of this yearShareCommentsByGraham HiscottHead of Business:,  JUN NewsIn some areas, more than one in three ATMs charge, while in worst-hit places, it is close to half"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAround  cash machines a day are being converted from free to charging – with US firms among those coining it in. Figures show nearly , fee-charging ATMs appeared in the first four months of this year. In some areas, more than one in three ATMs charge, while in worst-hit places, it is close to half. Many are in less well-off areas where people can least afford the fees. Caroline Abrahams, director of Age UK, said: “ATMs that charge are penalising the poorest pensioners.” Gareth Shaw, of consumer group Which , has said it risks harming “the most vulnerable the hardest”, adding: “A regulator is desperately needed.”  The situation has been worsened by bank and building society branches closing. Which  said in April that , had shut last year or were due to this year. Figures from Link, which connects most cash machines, show there were more than , ATMs in December, of which , charged. By April, the number was ,. Operators blame the rise on a cut by Link to the interchange fee paid by banks for running free-to-use ATMs. Most affected ATMs are run by Texas-based Cardtronics, which has said it is likely to convert , more machines in the coming months. story: NewsBride-to-be sheds five stone and goes from size  to size  in just four monthsSophie Matheson from Nottinghamshire has dropped five dress sizes after committing to a new fitness programme in the lead up to her weddingShareCommentsByHannah MitchellPippa Allen-Kinross:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsSophie dropped five stone in the four months before her wedding day "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA primary school teacher dropped an impressive five stone in just four months before her wedding day after embarking on a new fitness regime. Sophie Matheson, , dropped from a size  to a size  in just  weeks after getting in touch with a personal trainer. She got married in October and has since lost another stone, taking her total weight loss to six stone. Sophie, who works at Intake Farm Primary School in Mansfield, said: I had reached a point where I was dreading my wedding day. I was anxious about the photos, how I would look and feel in my dress and what others would think of me, and knew I had to do something to make a positive change.    She got in touch with local personal trainer Luke Hewitt after seeing some of his work on social media. Sophie, who lives in Ollerton, in Nottinghamshire, said she was nervous before her first session but was put at ease by Lukeaposs team. I started to see changes really quickly and began to develop a love for the gym, she told Nottinghamshire Live . She trained with Luke three times a week for  weeks in the lead up to her wedding day, with a programme that included a combination of cardiovascular exercise and weight training as well as a diet plan. Sophie said: My job as a primary school teacher can be quite stressful and fast paced and my diet before starting the programme reflected that. A typical day would have previously started with good intentions, with Weetabix for breakfast and fruit for my mid-morning snack, but then it would start to go downhill. Lunchtime would arrive and the staff room at work would be full of cakes and biscuits, so I’d help myself to those before grabbing a pre-packed wrap or sandwich for lunch. After work, I’d go to the shop and get crisps, sweets and chocolates and binge eat and then dinner would be something like wedges and a burger. We would also indulge in takeaways several times a week.”  Before she lost the weight, Sophie took  tablets a day for endometriosis and irritable bowel syndrome , but now she doesnapost take any medication at all. Sophie is a vegetarian and now keeps to a diet plan tailored for her. A typical day would consist of porridge or an omelette for breakfast, Quorn chilli, rice and salad for lunch and halloumi and vegetables kebabs with curried lentils for dinner, as well as ious snacks to keep her going throughout the day. She said: At first I couldnapost believe how much food I was able to eat. Iaposve tried every fad diet going so feeling satisfied rather than deprived made a huge dference to my motivation and sticking power. That, combined with my gym sessions, has completely changed my le for the better. I used to make excuses not to go out to social events and didnapost feel comfortable in anything I tried on. Now, I’m happier in all aspects of le: I’m more confident at work, have an even better relationship with my husband and I’m happier on holiday because I can wear what I want without feeling uncomfortable.”  By her wedding day, Sophie had got her weight down to  stone and wore a size  wedding dress. She has continued training and lost a further stone. She said: I felt amazing on my wedding day, and I definitely have Luke to thank for that, but for me this wasn’t just about losing weight for my wedding. story: NewsFrozen sperm bank could be set up in space says say scientistsScientists say the opportunity to create a reserve outside of Earth is a distinct possibilityShareCommentsBySally Wardle:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsScientists say more research needs to be done "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSperm banks could one day be set up in space, scientists have predicted. Frozen samples that were exposed to microgravity conditions and those kept in normal conditions appear to keep similar characteristics, according to the results of a small study, the Press Association has reported. The results of the research suggest frozen sperm could be sent into space and open the possibility of creating a human sperm bank outside of Earth. But more research is needed to fully understand the effect of space conditions, scientists have said.    The study was presented at the European Society of Human Reproduction and Embryology annual meeting in Vienna, Austria.The scientists conducting the study said little is known about the effect of dferent gravity levels on sperm.Dr Montserrat Boada, from Dexeus Womenaposs Health in Barcelona, said: Some studies suggest a signicant decrease in the motility of human fresh sperm sample. But nothing has been reported on the possible effects of gravitational dferences on frozen human gametes, in which state they could be transported from Earth to space.    The researchers used sperm from  healthy donors, exposing some of the samples to microgravity using a small aerobatic aircraft.The samples were then analysed for concentration, motility and DNA fragmentation - tests which are all performed to check for fertility.No signicant dferences were found between the samples kept on the ground and those exposed to microgravity, according to the study.

story: NewsopinionGirl, , and little sister, , taking on fast-food giants over plastic toysElla McEwan and her sister Caitlin were inspired to act after a family trip to Burger King - Their campaign has already attracted , signatures – and countingShareCommentsByNada Farhoud:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsopinionOn tomorrow night’s War on Plastic on BBC, the problem is laid bare showing millions of barely played with toys all adding to our mountain of plastic waste "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDespite our best efforts to clear up the plastic waste which has polluted the oceans, the responsibility to ensure we fully change our relationship with single-use items may now fall to the next generation. But the future is in safe handsnine-year-old Ella McEwan and her sister Caitlin, seven, are anything to go by. After learning at school how rubbish is endangering sea le, the eco-aware pair from Southampton set up an online petition for fast-food giants to stop putting plastic toys in children’s meal boxes. Inspired to act after a family trip to Burger King, their campaign has already attracted , signatures – and counting.  The girls said: “We like to go to eat at Burger King and McDonald’s but ­children only play with the plastic toys they give us for a few minutes before they get thrown away and harm animals and pollute the sea.” Staggeringly, McDonald’s is the largest toy distributor in the world, handing out more than . billion a year in a tsunami of single-use plastic. On tomorrow night’s War on Plastic on BBC One – hosted by Anita Rani – the problem is laid bare showing millions of toys – many unopened from fast-food meals and magazines, as well as Kinder Surprise eggs, all adding to our mountain of plastic waste. A new advert has also popped up on our TV screens to promote Cadbury Freddo Treasures. But this “treat” is more plastic waste than chocolate – a purple plastic treasure chest and plastic toy versus a handful of chocolate buttons.    Yes, in theory these toys can be recycled – as McDonald’s states on its website – but it is rarely economically viable to do so thanks to the mixture of plastics they are made from, meaning most still end up in landfill or being incinerated. The solution to this problem lies with the producers taking ­more responsibility for this mess. Help the girls out by signing their petition here .

story: NewsInside the £k house that no-one is allowed to enterLavender Cottage on the north coast of Cornwall has been off limits and sat derelict for yearsShareCommentsByGreg Martin:,  JUN NewsLavender Cottage has stood empty for years "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA photographer has been allowed inside a derelict building that has been off limits to the public for years.Lavender Cottage on the north coast of Cornwall is for sale with Camel Homes for offers in the region of just £,, CornwallLive has reported.The company selling the property have described it as an exciting development opportunity and, in their brochure where the house is listed, they ask any potential buyers have you got the imagination to turn this derelict property into the home of your dreams  If you’re looking to buy a house that is full of character and surrounded by nature, this property could be just for you. Imagination is necessary in spades however, because for this particular property, viewing is not essential, or even advised. In fact, potential buyers are warned ‘DO NOT enter the cottage UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES’. And since Lavender Cottage went up for sale in , firstly for £,, and then inviting offers in the region of £,, no-one has been allowed inside... until now.  Inside the abandoned Aleister Crowley house of West Cornwall  After following the old path on my hands and knees through the undergrowth for about  feet, I reach Lavender Cottage, completely hidden in a Cornish jungle of brambles and stinging nettles. Despite all the branches pushing into the building from every side like nature’s scaffolding, the structure looks decidedly unsafe, as warned. Nevertheless, I don my hard hat and delicately climb through the window.     The cottage is small and simple, with the ground floor split in half by a staircase iding what was once a lounge and a kitchen, leading upstairs to where there was once two bedrooms. The cottage features on historic maps dating back to .  The empty bottles of Corona also date back to the eighties, when people could redeem p when they ed the bottles to be recycled.In , UK Environment Secretary Michael Gove proposed that similar schemes were reintroduced to encourage people to recycle bottles by financial incentives.The  pence redeemable for the two Corona bottles is included in the price of the property.    Since this half drunken can of Coke was left on a rusting fridge, at least three decades have passed. The Berlin Wall has fallen, as have almost all of the interior walls in Lavender Cottage.  However, the cottage has not been untouched during that time. There are signs inside where repairs have started in earnest. Cob has been used to try and sure up some of the walls, as has concrete in places, such as around the old Rayburn.    In , a planning application for ‘alterations and erection of extension sites’ were ‘approved with conditions’. With the house derelict at this time, there are no obvious signs that these plans came to fruition.      Transforming the cottage from a two bedroomed house with no toilet into a three bedroomed home with bathroom and downstairs W.C., the plans appear to have been approved by Carrick District Council, but again, never became a reality.   The first Google Street View car to drive past Lavender Cottage, did so in June .A ‘WARNING KEEP OUT’ sign can be seen on the side of the house, which is still there today somewhere underneath the foliage. However, there appears to be repair work on the roof and front of the building, and a caravan on the land has its door open, asoccupied.    Lavender Cottage went on the market for £, with Camel Homes in , described as offering the ‘opportunity to live the dream in Cornwall and create your own perfect home’.    Despite the cottage being off limits to any prospective buyers, the estate agents say that they have had a lot of interest in the derelict property which sits on a plot of approximately . of an acre. However, no-one has snapped it up yet, and not being able to see inside it might not be the only factor putting people off.    The letter from Cornwall Council to the interested buyer concluded: “In summary the proposal that you have put forward for residential development through replacement for which Policy  of the Cornwall Local Plan is unlikely to be supported as the residential use on the site appears to have been abandoned. If you are minded to proceed with the development proposal on this site it is strongly recommended that you first obtain a Lawful Development Certicate to demonstrate that the existing home is in fact lawful.” What this essentially boils down to, is that planning permission to demolish Lavender Cottage and build a new home in its place is considered likely to be refused. So anyone who buys this property will have to work with what is already there, renovating the existing property as it stands.    Asthis old cottage wasn’t entangled enough with greenery, it is also now constrained by red tape. However, it doesn’t take too much of a stretch of the imagination to pull back the brambles and ivy and see this home as it once was, with its sunny garden and plentul orchard.    And standing inside Lavender Cottage, red tape to one side, it is easy to see how these crumbling walls could become a home once again.If you would like to find out more about Lavender Cottage, you can get details from  Camel Homes . Do not enter the property under any circumstances.

story: NewsWoman whose sugar daddy paid her way through university was scared hed kill herJessica Hyer, , from Manchester, says vulnerable girls are being lured into dangerous sex work by the promise of introductions to wealthy, generous mentorsShareCommentsByCharlotte Dobson:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsThe student was vulnerable and scared for her le "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA student who turned to sugar daddy dating after getting into debt has said she was scared for her le. Jessica Hyer was studying at the University in Manchester and originally planned for it to be a short-term fix, but it ended up having damaging long-term consequences for the vulnerable student. Becoming a ‘sugar baby’ on an established website was easy, but the ‘pay per dates’ arrangement soon became sex work for Jess.She became reliant on the large amounts of money she’d receive in exchange for dates and sex with older men, she told the Manchester Evening News.   It was quick cash for the desperate -year-old, who had supported herself since leaving home aged . For her, the reality of sugar daddy dating was far from glamorous. In fact, it was dangerous and isolating for Jess, who has been left traumatised by some of the encounters she had with so-called ‘sugar daddies’. Jess, who lives in south Manchester, now wants to lt the lid on apossugar daddy datingapos in a bid make young women and men aware of what it entails, and some of the risks. The -year-old is also setting up a support network for so-called apossugar babiesapos, offering them safety advice, someone to talk to and advice on how to get back into regular work. “The way sugar daddy dating has been glamorised is problematic,” says Jess. “There are vulnerable girls and there are underrage girls who lie about their age on those websites. “Don’t get me wrong, there are some girls who love it and have successful relationships with men on there. All the power to those. “But the ones who need support, and have had awful experiences like myself, that’s what is important to me. “People shouldn’t think it’s all rosy and glamorous because it’s not.” Jess grew up on Stoops Estate in Burnley, one of the most impoverished postcodes in the UK, and left home when she was . She went to college before gaining a place at the University of Manchester to study English and Drama.  A year into her studies, Jess was in what she describes as ‘financial ruin’. She was £ overdrawn and owed her friend £. The earnings from her part-time job as a waitress weren’t going to pay the debts she owed.Then, an advert popped up on her Facebook feed featuring a ‘sugar daddy dating’ website.“They target students and you actually get a free premium accountyou have a student email,” says Jess.  “When you look at the page there’s an image of a young attractive man. “They make you think that these men are mentors and, that they are going to help you with your career, men who don’t view you in a sexual way. “When really, sex is usually the end goal, she said. Jess said it soon became apparent that ‘sugar daddy dating’ wasn’t a scenario where an older, wealthy man lavishes a younger girl with gts or long-term financial support. Instead, men were using it as a way to pay students for sex. At first she would meet men for dates only, making between £ to £ per meet. But as her financial circumstances became more desperate, she agreed to have sex with the men she met online for much larger sums of cash. On the first arrangement of this kind, Jess was picked up from her student house in Fallowfield by a man driving a Lamborghini. “My first proper, proper sugar daddy messaged saying ‘a dinner and a date and a night at mine for a grand’,” says Jess. “I’d never been on a date like that but I was desperate so I had to take the risk. “I got in his Lambo and he passed me a grand in cash, a wad of £ notes with a ring around it. I’d never seen that amount of money before. “That was one of the few glamorous occasions of sugar daddy dating for me. “I was so scared I askedI could get out the car and post the money through the door in case he killed me. “I felt I had so little choice at the time I just did it.” Jess estimates she met with around  men through a website over four years. The men she’d meet were usually in their forties and fties with a iety of jobs and backgrounds. Some were wealthy businessmen or doctors, but some she knew very little about. “They don’t all have loads of money,” adds Jess. “In fact, some are really tight.” What sugar daddies seek from sugar babies ies, Jess says. Some want to take the girls on dates and have the ‘girlfriend experience’, while some ask for arrangements where there are no sexual limitations and want to indulge fetishes. Jess said she often hid the seedy reality of sugar daddy dating from her friends. “Some of my friends thought it was really fun and glamorous but that was only because I didnapost tell anyone what it was really like, most women don’t,” she added. “Most of us wouldn’t admit what it’s really like unless it’s to another sugar baby.  “I sugarcoated it at the time because I didn’t want anyone to know what I was really doing. “I did feel a lot of shame because of the way men and women view sex work. But you can’t deny that it’s happening and it’s not going to stop.” Jess said the longer she did sugar daddy dating, the more risks she took. It all started to have a severe effect on her mental health. She said she was left traumatised by some of her experiences with men who paid her, and has had therapy to recover. “Once you get into it you get used to the money and it’s hard to get out,” says Jess. “You start lowering your standards and you start taking risks because you need the money. “And when you get the money you spend because you think ‘this is an easy le’. “I was making up to £ a date sometimes, but not all the time. “It was enough to support myself but also my problems. “My mental health severely deteriorated around this time and it was heavily influenced by what I was doing. “I felt so isolated and there was no support for people like me at the time. “There’s nothing for the girls to chat on the site I used. “I’d reported a number of users to the site and never got a response. “None of it is taken seriously. “I’m not saying that all the men on there are not nice. “But in my experience the vast majority of men don’t treat you like you’re human. A sugar daddy once said to me, aposI usually go for girls who are less pretty like you because they are less confidentapos. “To them you’re an investment and a sexual investment.” Jess managed to extract herself from sugar daddy dating last year. With therapy and the support of her partner, Jess has taken control of her mental health and is recovering from some of her experiences.    Her aim is to get a job as a mental health support worker and start her masters in applied theatre in the autumn. Her sugar babies support group will be open to students turning to sex work through websites to fund their time at university. “I managed to get out of sugar daddy dating and I want to be part of that process for other people. “I want people to know that I’m not judging those with a positive experience. “I personally had a terrible experience and at the time I felt there wasn’t any support available to me “I want to provide that support for men and women without judgment.” The Manchester Evening News has contacted the website Jess used for a response.

title: inside spoilt brat kim jong
story: NewsInside spoilt brat Kim Jong-uns bizarre North Korean childhoodThe dictator was raised in lavish homes believing he was a "demigod" - and was given his first car aged sevenShareCommentsByDave Burke:,  JUN NewsKim Jong-un with his mother Ko Yong Hui "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAs a spoiled young boy who was given his first car aged just seven, Kim Jong-un was raised to believe he was a demigod. His parents ensured he had staff tending to his every need, and the gardens of his home were filled with cages containing monkeys and bears for his entertainment. Huge playrooms boasted more toys than any European store and the gardens inside the walled compounds where he was raised were so large that many called them parks. A personal chef was hired to be the future North Korean dictatoraposs friend - and the young Kim would don military gear to boss adults around. Thataposs according to a new book about the feared world leader, who executed his uncle and had his half-brother killed with a nerve agent.  Washington Post journalist Anna Field has chronicled his le as a child and as a teenager sent to study in Switzerland in new book The Great Successor. The son of former Supreme Leader Kim Jong-il - who died in  - and grandson of the countryaposs founder, Kim Il-sung, he was a spoiled brat in childhood. Contact with other children was scarce, Field writes, with his eighth birthday party attended by high-ranking adults instead of other children. In an interview with Vox, Field said: He was brought up to believe that he was a demigod from the age of three or four, probably as long as he can remember.  Even when North Koreans were plunged into famine, Kim was probably unaware of the horric conditions they were enduring, she believes. Determined to give the young boy the same mythical status afforded to his father and grandfather, propagandists claimed Kim was such a good marksman that he could hit a lightbulb from  metres. When he was eight, it was claimed he could drive a truck at mph. The author said he was close to his mother, Ko Yong Hui, from who he got the belief that he was a military genius, as well as a love of basketball.  Her influence was seen everywhere from the cartoons of her that suddenly started appearing on TV to the way her sons were promoted and moved up the ranks, Field stated. In the s Kim was sent to live and study at the International School of Bern in Switzerland under a  identity. This was done in the hope that exposure to the West would turn him into a reformer - but the author said the opposite was true. She told Vox: What his time in Switzerland must have taught him is thatit wasn’t for the family myth and family dynasty, he’d be a nobody. Knowing that without his connections he would be another ordinary, chubby immigrant kid going to school and struggling with his math homework, he decided to perpetuate the system.  Although he would kick and spit on his fellow students in fits of anger and frustration, Field said there is no evidence of Kim being a pyschopath - and he did make four close friends. He would regularly play basketball after school, watched by his uncle and aunt who acted as his s. They would set up picnic-like chairs and cheer him on - something classmates found odd.When he did take over from his father in , many thought the dynasty would collapse within months. But Field writes that his every move is calculated to ensure he stays in power.  Under Kim, the country carried out its first successful hydrogen bomb test in , and has developed a new generation of cyber hackers. Field believes that Kim is very consciously trying to look like his grandfather, who is still revered in North Korea. And Kimaposs ruthlessness has not seen members of his immediate family spared. Half-brother Kim Jong-nam died after being attacked with a nerve agent at Kuala Lumpar International Airport in Malasia in . While his death is regarded officially as an assassination, it is thought of by many as a public execution.  Although it has never been proved, Kim is believed to have ordered the killing, believing his half-brother was a threat. Four North Korean suspects left the airport shortly after the assassination and left Korea without being arrested. And his uncle Jang Song Thaek - described in North Korean media as despicable human scum, worse than a dog - was reportedly fed to  hungry dogs in .

title: man dresses up lion costume
story: NewsMan dresses up in lion costume for drill in case big cat escapes at zooLions at Tobe Zoo in Ehime, south Japan managed to subdue the fake lionShareCommentsByMilo Boyd:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsA human size lion put zoo keepers through their paces "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJapanese zoo keepers have been prepping for a potentially deadly lion escape by chasing a man in an animal suit. Staff at Tobe Zoo in Ehime, south Japan carried out the emergency drill on Saturday. Instead of using a real lion an employee donned a furry suit and large mascot head. The clip begins with the ferocious beast wandering somewhat aimlessly down a concrete road. After looking around dubiously for some prey, it opts to walk away from four men holding up a net with poles.    An official looking man in a blue unorm does eventually catch the big cataposs eye, prompting the King of the Jungle to race towards him. The man is thrown backwards but fortunately his colleagues hold firm, rebuffing the flesh hungry mammal.    A small white van then appears and crawls alongside of the lion. Out of its windows a zoo worker aims a gun towards at the brown and yellow animal, firing a singular shot.    As a pair of real lions look on, the mascot-like feline staggers to the floor. A long poll is threaded through the window which pokes the animal, making sure it is firmly out of action before workers rush over to restrain them.    Mascot costume culture is particularly prominent in Japan. Yuru-chara for example, is just one category of many mascot categories. With unsophisticated and cute looks, yuru-chara characters represent towns and their history, culture or produce.

title: 172 at the caird perfect for our kids free relaxing date
story: We wanted to have a civilised date night to celebrate the news I am expecting another baby.I fancied something nicer than McDonald’s with the kids or a takeaway pizza on the sofa, before our brood grows by one more. at the Caird is a chic, modern venue in a refurbished former jute mansion on Perth Road – the perfect choice for a calm and child-free evening. vw, px"  I’d been to the Caird for coffees and drinks in its cocktail and wine bar, so I was aware of the tastefully designed interior and stunning views across the Tay, and I was keen to see how its food matched up.The vibe was certainly calm when we entered the reception and were escorted into an almost empty dining room. vw, px"  It was a glorious evening and the sun was streaming into the room, so we opted for a table by the large window, perfect for people-watching on the main road, next to the glossy black grand piano – classy.My partner ordered a Rekorderlig ciderand even now I can’t hide the disappointment I feel at not being able to order a cocktail. Especially here, where they have an extensive menu dedicated to them categorised by flavour and even offer “cocktail experiences” for those looking to learn from their mixologists. Our waiter recommended a real fruit mocktail with lots of real crushed fruit and berries and juices to provide a thirst quenching mix without the alcohol .We relaxed into the quiet and sipped our drinks in the sun as we pondered over the vast menu options.The venue’s interior is a mix of classic wooden floors with soft leathers and muted tartans in greys and brown, combining traditional charm with modern comfort. vw, px"  The menus are bound in heavy leather books, and there was plenty of choice.My other half ordered bruschetta to startwhich, of course, we ended up sharing. Well, I am eating for two!Who knew that three simple slices of toasted bread with oils and tomato could be so delicious  Also, both of us were pretty in awe of the little yellow tomatoes – spot the uncultured pair.I toyed with the idea of my usual steak pie-pick and even deliberated a fish dish, but in the end we both went for the same main course of chicken tikka curryand it was presented beautully.The plate held rice and naan with a small dish of mango chutney and a large dish of gorgeously bright-coloured chicken tikka.The chicken was wonderfully soft and the tikka sauce was full of flavour, not too salty with just a bit of zing. vw, px"  I’m notoriously soft when it comes to anything spicy, but this was just enough for me and I only needed water for my tingly lips towards the end of finishing the plateful.We were both equally surprised at the portion size from the Caird. Although it felt upmarket, there was no scrimping on the food.I chose the brownie for dessert and my partner the sticky toffee pudding . Again, both platefuls looked almost too good to eat.My dark chocolate brownie was topped with drizzled caramel sauce next to a scoop of vanilla ice cream with sprinkles of crushed chocolate and chocolate sauce. Strawberries and homemade fudge was presented to the side in a design with shards of wafer and small dollops of salted caramel and strawberry mousse. It sounds like a lot of flavours and it was, but in a good way.My partner’s slab of sticky toffee pudding was also teamed with a large scoop of ice cream, crushed chocolate, a large wafer and a couple of raspberries, sprinkled with icing sugar.We both finished the lot.The whole evening was lovely and relaxing. We could hear the live musicians in the bar from where we were seating which provided great listening. The staff were also fantastic, extremely helpful, attentive and polite.

title: letters to the editor week 18 2
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,I read with interest the article in the April  edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser about the council’s autism strategy.I find it strange Councillor Green said the #strategy has reached a draft stage# when an Autism Strategy for Argyll and Bute already exists.It was commissioned by the council, produced in May  and signed off by council members. An implementation plan was produced in December  to cover the years -. Who in Argyll and Bute is responsible for this plan  How many of the outcomes have been achieved As someone who has been involved with autism personally and professionally for many years, I find it extremely disappointing there seems to be an inability by those in authority to get organised enough to address the issues and provide services for autistic people and their families.There is no need for further drafts and consultations.Someone in the authority needs to take responsibility for the existing strategy and implementation plan and get on with it.Maureen Mackintosh, Ardrishaig.Sir,Scotland’s small building firms had a strong start to , in contrast to the UK construction small and medium sized enterprisesector, according to the Federation of Master BuildersScotland.The FMB State of Trade Survey for the first quarter of , the only quarterly assessment of the UK-wide SME construction sector, showed SME workloads declined for the first time in six years.In Scotland, however, there was a jump of  per cent compared with the previous quarter. Thirty per cent of weighted responses were positive, up from  per cent from the fourth quarter of .It is encouraging the Scottish construction industry is bucking the wider Brexit trend with workloads and enquires in rude health. The UK-wide picture is very dferent, with the construction SME sector overall contracting for the first time in six years.Scotland’s good fortune could be due to fewer EU workers being based north of the border compared with other parts of the country, like in London where one in three construction workers are from the EU.Relying less heavily on migrant workers has meant the Scottish construction industry hasn’t fallen foul of thousands of EU workers ing home during the long march to Brexit due to no longer feeling welcome in the UK or sure of their future here.Scotland’s builders, however, must not be complacent. Looking ahead, the First Minister has indicated thatthe UK does leave the EU later this year, she wants a second independence referendum before the next Scottish Parliament election in . This additional political uncertainty, on top of the continued uncertainty stemming from Brexit, could impact on the construction sector in Scotland.The fear is a looming second referendum could test consumer confidence this year and next. For construction SMEs, this is particularly concerning as their prospects are vulnerable to dips in consumer confidence as so much work comes from the private domestic sector.Gordon Nelson, Director of FMB Scotland.Sir,I was joined by my fellow Conservative councillors in Kilmory recently as we discussed atthe numerous challenges facing Argyll and Bute.Ferry sailings, roads, education and the SNP#s late single farm payments were all mentioned.With the SNP hammering local authority spending and cutting our budgets, challenges in delivering services will become more prevalent.Despite this climate of cuts from the separatists, Conservative councillors are delivering for Argyll. This includes extra funding for the Tarbert and Lochgilphead Regeneration Fund, more funding for infrastructure and an increase in roads winter maintenance resources across Argyll.As ever, my fellow Conservatives and I will continue to fight non stop to make sure our rural constituency is not sidelined by this unceasingly urban and separatism-obsessed over centralising Scottish Government.Councillor Alastair Redman, Kintyre and Islands ward.Sir,I photographed this unusual visitor to Kilduskland Road, Ardrishaig, on April . Magpies are not a regular feature in Mid Argyll. We have not seen one in more than  years here.I think I saw a second one, either in pursuit or being pursued.Ron MacInnes, Ardrishaig.PIC:The Ardrishaig magpie, spotted in April. no_aMagpie

title: fynefest celebrates turning 10 with a beer
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowFyneFest s for , celebrating hitting double figures with as much flair as ever.Beer, food and music: what more could anyone ask for  And there#s going to be plenty of each at this unique event, held over four days from Friday May .As usual, the field will be filled with trucks serving everything from pizza to curry and cupcakes. The most important part is the surprises amongst the favourites. Glasgow-based Samba Ya Bamba is a -piece brass band that will be heard before being seen.But that is the tip of the iceberg. Musicians from all over will offer everything from folk to rock to ceilidh and blues.As for the beer, this event proves to be the connoisseur of the pint-size world. More than  beers from  breweries are served at the main bar, with others in the Courtyard. There is also a cocktail teepee and cider is available. title: letters to the editor 31 5 19
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,Councillors# and council officers# opposition to the Airigh Wind Farm proposal is disappointing.It is tenuous to say that a #jumbled# appearance of the turbines from the seaward south west approaches is a valid point for rejection.The preservation of panoramic quality does not provide for the social economic benefit to the rural community.Managing and improving the community-owned assets with today#s dearth of public funds and grants is challenging.Ardrishaig Community Trust is funding the renovation of our public hall solely with funds saved from a modest investment in the Allt Dearg Wind Farm.Should the proposed scheme have gone ahead there would have been an opportunity to invest in the enterprise, thus providing a signicant value revenue stream. That revenue would have contributed towards the management and improvement of assets and development of services within the Ardrishaig area for years ahead and for the benefit of current and future generations.Edward Laughton, director, Ardrishaig Community TrustSir,We often hear Argyll and Bute Council being slated.But this time they deserve all the praise they can get for cleaning and re-pointing Lochgilphead War Memorial. All it took was a request and the work was done in time for the Lochgilphead Armed Forces Day on June .Geordie Rhodick, chairman, LAFDSirFor the past two years, since he was elected to Argyll and Bute Council by the skin of his teeth, Councillor Alastair Redman has bombarded local newspapers with a constant stream of drivel attacking the Scottish Government.In his latest diatribe, he alleges that #the SNP has completely misjudged the mood of voters up and down the country#.I know it will be extremely painful for him, buthe can bring himself to review last week’s European Election results in Scotland, he’ll see the complete fallacy of this statement, andhe wants to look even closer to home, he’ll see that the SNP polled , votes in Argyll and Bute – , votes ahead of the Tories who came a distant fourth.Hardly a sign of his mythical assertion that Ruth Davidson is poised to be the next First Minister of Scotland.Robert Macintyre, Serpentine Road, RothesayDear PaulI write on behalf of constituents in Tarbert regarding the application for the Inveraray to Crossaig kV overhead line, which is with the [Scottish Government] Energy Consents Unit.A very large number of constituents have contacted me regarding this matter and almost  have signed a petition.They believe the proposal will have a major deleterious effect on the village and will be a huge and ugly blot on the landscape which, given the very attractive and scenic nature of the area, will be a big disincentive to tourism and will spoil the enjoyment of the area for residents as well.I have met with SSE to discuss this issue and have made it clear to them that the community wishes the company to come forward with alternative proposals, which must include undergrounding the cableno route can be found which does not spoil the visual amenity of the village.I know that the new line is needed for entirely understandable and positive reasons, and I have had only a few complaints from other parts of the area which will be affected.The opposition in Tarbert is virtually unanimous and there is also concern being expressed from those who know and value the area but do not live there.I hope that any consideration of consent will ensure that this issue is dealt with in accordance with the views of local people and I would be grateful to hear from you what the timescale is for that decision .Michael RussellSir,Newly-elected UK MEPs will take their seats in the European Parliament in July and it is crucial they recognise their signicant role in shaping the policies that impact on farming businesses. This new parliament will be pivotal in determining the nature of our future regulatory environment and we are keen and ready to meet with them.Our industry faces a number of challenges over the coming years, not just in relation to Brexit but on issues such as climate change, environmental policy, plant protection and animal health and welfare. There will also be opportunities for farming and we must ensure that we make the most of these opportunities to build a forward-looking, progressive and resilient sector that benefits farmers and consumers throughout the UK.We would like to invite all UK MEPs on to farms in their local areas to discuss a range of priority issues and to answer any questions that they might have. We are also inviting them to meet with us in person in Brussels and with our permanent staff in our Brussels office, the British Agriculture Bureau.Andrew McCornickMinette BattersJohn Daviesand Ivor Ferguson
